plist.p: Well, good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. It's great for us to have the opportunity to explain what we've been up to in the first half of the year. And so, we'll get straight to it. In April, I described some decisive actions that we were taking, including important changes that we were making to shape the future growth of Tesco and I'm pleased to be able to report progress in a number of these areas.

Firstly, in the UK, where we've started on our journey to improve the shopping trip for customers and we're stabilizing the performance of the business. Second, having taken actions to reduce our level of new space growth in the UK and given more focus to driving the performance of our existing stores, I'm even more certain that that's the right thing for us to have done. Third, we've invested in extending our reach, our range and our capability online. Fourth, at Tesco Bank, 2.8 million credit card customers enjoyed a smooth transition from the RBS systems to our own. And fifth, we agreed a deal with Aeon, confirming our exit from Japan.

So, we're getting stuck in to making necessary changes in our business. But, of course, things have not gone all our own way. Whilst we didn't expect the European economy to improve, the continued uncertainty and the very real financial pressures experienced by households across Central Europe have taken their toll. And in Korea, the emerging shopping hour regulations I described in April have had a material impact on sales and on profitability and they're going to continue to do so for some time to come.

Meanwhile, Fresh & Easy is not where we want it to be. Losses have improved slightly before the impact of currency and like-for-like sales did pick up in the second quarter. But I said in June that we needed more from Fresh & Easy and that remains the case today. Accordingly, future capital will be very tightly constrained. I'm going to come back to each of those challenges a little bit later on.

But when we last met, I described how I believe the industry in the UK had been running up the down escalator, and how we were going to take a different approach in the future. Less space growth overall, fewer new, big stores, more focus on smaller stores, and more focus on driving growth through our existing stores and our Internet offer. I'm even more convinced today that that was the right call. And that's not just because others have followed our lead on space, although that's certainly good from an industry perspective. It's because I've seen what a difference we can make by redirecting some of our capital expenditure into our existing stores, into making superstores and Extras the beating heart of Tesco in the UK, the very best stores they can possibly be.

And finally, it's because when customers do have money to spend on general merchandise and on electronics, they're increasingly looking to a different source of retail experience, more clicks than bricks. Any retailer who wants to survive long term needs to have a strong offer online. And I believe that any retailer who wants to win in the long term needs to be multichannel. And so, as you know, we're investing more online and are reducing our opening program for large stores. We're building more Expresses and investing a greater proportion of our total capital expenditure on our existing stores, reflecting the fact that refreshes and remodels must be our clear priority. That will be good for us and it will be good for customers. It will also be good for our shareholders. It'll support improved performance, it'll lead to better returns, and it'll drive stronger cash generation.

It's been a very important half year for our UK business. We committed significant revenue and capital investment to improving the shopping trip for customers and our plans for building a better Tesco are on track. Customers have started to notice and respond to the changes we've made and our trading performance has begun to show some signs of improvement.

When I first laid out the plans to you in April, I described them in terms of six key areas. And I'll use that to give you a brief progress update this morning. Before I do that, though, what's really happening here is that Tesco is changing. It's running less hot, it's loving the stores we have, it's reducing new store growth, it's competing harder online. It's a very different Tesco than it was two years ago. It'll be a very different Tesco in two years' time.

But now, into the details. On service & staff, we've completed the recruitments, the training, and the deployment of 8,000 colleagues we said we'd put back into our existing superstores, Extras and into a few of our metros. That work was done in two phases. The first of those phases focused on the fresh food department, and that was done by the end of Q1.

The second phase, which extends into other parts of the store, only a few weeks ago, that was completed, and that's gone mainly into the food and grocery departments. I think if you visit our stores today, you can begin to see the results; improving standards, improving availability, improving presentation of products and most notably, in fresh foods.

In April, I described that the like-for-like sales improvement of 1.1% from the first phase of labor in our 200-store pilot was a good start. That level of uplift was maintained as we went from the 200 to the 500 other large stores. And as you know, our overall sales performance has improved a little bit against the market, a testament to the hard work of all of our 300,000 colleagues.

Importantly, customer perceptions of availability, service and quality, as you can see in this chart, have all started to show signs of improvement. I'm particularly pleased that the 8,000 extra staff have resulted in the staff visibility going up by 17 percentage points. Top left, even of more importance, the fresh food looking well cared for, up 11%, that's Q1 on Q2 in the stores that have had the investment.

Our work on stores and formats, that's also made progress. It's got two main parts, refreshing the look and feel of our existing estate and then, ensuring that our new space program is fit for purpose. On refresh, we've completed over 230 stores in the first half. The refreshed stores, I hope you can see, look warmer, better signed, easier to shop, and I hope that many of you get the opportunity to see a few during our Investor Tour next month.

We've also started to reallocate space in some of our existing stores. The building a better Tesco plan is a food-first one and we've been giving space back to food in some of our stores, where we previously tried to fit in a bit too much non-food.

I'll give you an example, if I may. You may know that I was with the UK team and the odd journalist in Bishop's Stortford last week. It's a great store. It's in a great location. It's been there for more than 20 years. But six months ago, it wasn't the best food shop in town. It is today.

You can see what we've done here and look at the floor plan, how before and after. We've reduced the amount of non-food by 20%. We've given it back to food. Customers used to walk through the doors and see this. And now they see this. I know which one they prefer and I know which one I prefer.

On new space, we're on track for around a 40% reduction year-on-year, with a much bigger proportion of what we opened going into Express. In fact last week, the Café Matthiae in Richmond became the 1,500th Express store in Richmond.

We described our plans to deliver better vendor price promotions, coupons and loyalty as price and value in April and we've made some good progress in this area, too. Our investment in on-shelf pricing this time last year has resulted in better prices for customers, but our price perception suffered because of the increased couponing in the market and the promotions by some of our competitors in Q4.

We've continued our budgeting investment in price in the first half, made our promotions clearer and sharper and we made them more relevant for customers. And we've corrected the low level of couponing that we ran in Q4.

More importantly, though, we launched Clubcard Bonus in the first half. We mail over 7 million customers with highly personalized offers. And this is in between our normal quarterly Clubcard statements. These mailings offer customer discounts or points on the products that matter most to them. The initial mailings have been incredibly successful. Customers love them and we've seen much higher redemption rates and better sales-to-cost ratios than previous mailings, all thanks to dunnhumby. Clubcard Bonus is reinforcing loyalty and building trust in the company.

One of the first and most tangible changes we made in the stores was the successful re-launch of Tesco Value as Everyday Value, and hopefully, you had a chance to see it outside when you were on the way in. Since its launch back in April, nearly 80% of customers across all demographics have bought the new range. Sales of that range are growing more than 10% faster than the business as a whole. And even last week, we added another 100 products to the range, including new frozen and chilled convenience lines.

And my dad was telling me last night, he went into Walton and bought five ready meals, five ready meals for a fiver. But being 84, he tried to defrost it, didn't realize he could cook it from frozen. It didn't go as well as he expected. Hopefully, his tea will be all right tonight. This is important, of course, because consumers are very hard pressed. Look at the rise of the discounters. This is one of the ways in which we can compete, and I'm very pleased with the performance. Well done to the team, some of them whom are here today helped develop it.

Range and quality work's also begun, though, on the new – on the core Tesco range. We have 2,000 new or upgraded products under the Tesco brand so far. Notable improvements in the first half include the re-launch of our bakery offer that you'll have seen upstairs. Don't worry, that equipment is headed to a store near you soon, so it's not going to waste and the bakery product, please, take it on the way out and enjoy it, including 30 new artisanal breads and a brand new patisserie range.

And in chilled ready meals, significant quality upgrades, packaging improvement, and better range segmentation. That work's got a long, long way to go, but week by week, there are more and more new upgraded products appearing on the shelf. As an example, we will be re-launching our entire fresh meat category in just under a month, supported by an improved store presentation.

Now, what do I mean by all that? Well, this is what I mean by that. This is a picture I took of Amersham store last year. You can – it was taken with my phone; not a particularly good picture. I wouldn't have been proud of it anyway, even before we put up the sign saying we thought you might be a shoplifter, and if you are, we'll send you to prison. I never thought they'd let me show it publicly. And the reason that they said that I could was, this is the photo not taken by me of that same department from that same angle last week. It's a lot better, isn't it?

A meat department Dad would have been proud of in his store in Allerton and one I am proud of. And it's not just presentation, because it isn't in the end about presentation and wooden fixtures. That's a nice backdrop. What it's about is a review of the product itself. 150 products will be upgraded. New lines will be introduced, improve the cut, hanging our beef for longer, and seeking out the very best products. That's what I mean when I say building a better Tesco.

In July, we appointed Wieden + Kennedy, our first new creative agency in over 15 years. They're going to be heavily involved in our brand and marketing work and be helping us to have the different conversation we know that we need to have with our customers. I'm not going to share the output of that work today but you'll start to see the first signs of the new marketing campaign before the end of the year.

Personalization and localization are very key to our plan. For most people, the Tesco brand is defined by the stores that they visit each week. Ensuring that each store has the strongest, the most relevant range for its customers is a key step along the journey to winning increased loyalty.

We have the systems. We have the processes. We have the supply chain to do it. We're now using them in a way that we weren't using them before. Tailored ranges to different catchments have been launched in grocery categories such as bottled water, herbs and spices.

Here's an example of how we've improved the segmentation of our wine offer. More upmarket in some stores, we have finest and even a fine wine selection and in others, more focused on helping customers find what they want, with recommendations like the Simply range, Great With range and a block of Special Offers for those who don't know much about it, just want a good deal or something with fish or, you know, I've heard of Sauvignon Blanc, let's just get one that's nice and simple. The insight and capability provided by dunnhumby underpin all these and there is a lot more to come.

So far, I've talked about the first five elements of the building a better Tesco plan. Care about retailing basics, they are very necessary improvements. They're long overdue. But the sixth element is very, very different. Our clicks and bricks strategy is a sea-change for us, and I think, for the industry. I've said it before, but it means less big new stores. It means greater digital connections to our customers. It means starting here at home. But it means spreading it around our world. We're determined to be a winner in the Internet revolution, not a victim of it.

We've brought new innovations to our online grocery business in the first half. Already the leading online grocer in the world, in May, we became the first mainstream retailer in the UK to offer our customers a subscription service, which enables them to save money when they place regular orders at tesco.com, £36 for a quarter, as many deliveries as you want. 70,000 customers have taken up that offer.

It's very popular, unsurprisingly, amongst our most loyal customers. Average basket size for customers using the Delivery Saver is slightly larger than our grocery.com service as a whole. We've also accelerated the rollout of Click & Collect for groceries, with drive-through collection points like this one at Seaton's store, now in 90 stores across the country. You don't even have to get out your car, have your shopping put in the boot.

We've made considerable progress, too, on Tesco Direct. We started 2012 with 38,000 items available online. In April, it was 75,000 to do. Today, it's 200,000 and growing at about 10,000 a week. It includes products sold now by 14 third-party marketplace sellers, who've already signed up to sell products through the Tesco website.
We've also increased the number of Click & Collect desks, like this one, to over 1,300, with more than a third of these in Express stores, bringing a new level of convenience to customers.

We've also taken some significant steps towards the creation of a complete digital entertainment service online. We complimented Blinkbox, which is video streaming, with further acquisitions, buying the Internet radio service We-7 in the first half and the e-book platform Mobcast just last month. Together, these businesses give us the building blocks to provide a credible, innovative offer for our customers.

But, of course, there's much more to do and much more that can be done. One of the exciting aspects of this work in the UK is that every change that we've made sparks another set of opportunities, things that we can do even better. And I am continuing to devote a significant amount of my time to the UK. It's still the biggest priority for the group as a whole.

It's genuinely a team effort and the management team that's now been in place for over six months, is strong, it's experienced and as driven as any I could want. Now, you're going to hear today in the audience is thanks to this team, thanks to you meeting in Baldock with me every week, that we've achieved the progress that we have so far.

I'll turn now to our businesses outside the UK. We've been challenged by two factors; the Eurozone crisis and its effect on consumers in Europe, the trading hour restrictions in our biggest market, South Korea. Both have been significant and both have impacted performance, especially difficult for us in a year when we had big investments in the UK.

To give you a bit more color on Korea, back in April, we knew that the passing of regulations allowing regional authorities to impose opening hour restrictions on all large retailers in the market would have some impact. Initially, it wasn't clear how many regions would apply these restrictions or how severe to individual stores they would be.

By the end of July, however, 24-hour trading had been prohibited in all of our stores and we were having to close every other Sunday in almost every region across the country. These restrictions hit Homeplus hard. Our stores typically be more than 20% of trade on a Sunday. And one of the things that customers particularly enjoyed about Homeplus was that more of our stores were trading on a 24-hour basis than any of our competitors.

None of this changes the fact that Homeplus is one of our most successful, highest returning businesses outside the UK, but it does mean that its profitability will continue to be severely impacted whilst the regulations are in place. Elsewhere in Asia, our third largest market talent had a good first half. Sales and profits up on top of a strong performance in the first half last year. They opened 150 Express stores in the first half, and they will be the first of our businesses outside the UK to have 1,000 convenience stores trading, and that will happen in the next few months. We're going to take a step towards being a multichannel business in Thailand with the launch of grocery home shopping in Bangkok later in the year.

In China, the more cautious stance we described in April is serving us well, in a market where new store development was significantly outpacing consumer demand. Many retailers putting down more space in the market; few seeing that translate into profitable growth. We'll still open 16 hypermarkets in China this year, and that, as you remember, is only part of the program that we'd originally planned for the year. The new focus has enabled us to scale back our regional and our central overheads, and showing it's more appropriately sized for the current pace of growth in the business. China remains strategically important for us. But as I've said before, it's more of a marathon than a sprint.

In Europe, we expect it to be tough for some time to come. Consumer confidence in almost every one of our markets is lower than at the same point last year, and many households are facing real financial pressures. Take the Czech Republic for example, already one of the worst-affected markets by the crisis, but customers hit by a 4% increase in the lowest rate of VAT at the start of the year, and there's already talk of a further increase later this year. There's increasing unemployment, there's falling disposable income, and that's taken its toll on like-for-like, particularly in the second quarter.

While general merchandise and electronic sales have been impacted across the region, clothing has picked up, as the F&F offer continues to be sought after by customers, and the range is increasingly benefiting from our skill and our scale, because we've combined the buying, merchandising and creative teams across the region with the UK, leading to quality, price and design improvements from which the UK itself is beginning to benefit as well.

Let's not forget the big picture either. What's happening in the UK is going to happen in Europe. The Internet is the fastest-growing retail channel. We are proud that Tesco grocery home shopping has launched in cities including Warsaw, Kraków, Poznan, and Wroclaw in Poland, in addition to Prague in the Czech Republic, and just a few weeks ago, in Bratislava in Slovakia.

Our investment in the future in Europe will be more focused than ever on smaller format stores and the emerging online channel. Both will benefit from our skill and our scale, as we can deploy our blueprint format and our systems quickly and in a very capital-efficient way because of the capability that you know we have in Bangalore. Over half the space that we've opened since the start of the year in Europe is in smaller stores, including the 30 new franchise stores in the Czech Republic for Zabka.

At Fresh & Easy, whilst their offer continues to improve, the performance of the business is not where we wanted it to be. Although losses came down slightly before the impact of exchange rates, they didn't come down as much as we would have liked. Our like-for-like sales performance got better in the second quarter, but weighed down by a disappointing first quarter.

More of our existing stores have crossed over the store profitability line. We're going to focus our efforts even more in the second half on getting further stores across the line in the second half. But I am very clear that Fresh & Easy needs to do better and as a consequence, we're keeping an even firmer grip on new capital for the business. We'll open only a handful of stores in the months ahead.

Four months on from the migration of the final credit card account, we can be proud of the bespoke modern bank we've created through our 7 million existing banking and insurance customer accounts. It's always difficult for us to make decisions that affect the short-term performance of the business, and slowing down the project added in additional cost and delayed the marketing of new and existing products.

However, when I look at the bank today, I know it was the right call for the long-term, ensuring a smooth transition for our credit card customers and avoiding the substantial systems issues faced by others in the retail banking sector.

The bank has now resumed the launch of its new products, starting with mortgages, launched softly in August. Prices (26:04) will follow in November. And we've picked up the pace of marketing existing products, introducing new loan rates and new credit card deals. Tesco Bank is getting back to growing again. Free from migration, it can pick up the rates of its profit growth in future years and that will be important.

But another measure, and equally as important, of the success of the bank is the contribution it makes to the UK. It will be a powerful driver of loyalty, achieved by offering great value, relevant products and services to millions of Tesco customers, provided by Tesco people using Tesco systems, not a third party. Tesco people, Tesco systems, Tesco products.

In summary, and for now, we've embarked upon our journey to build a better Tesco. The key first step was to make the right calls. And I believe we've done that, on the UK, on space growth and on capital. Having made those calls, we've got on with implementing change, improving our execution in the UK, stabilizing the performance of the business, reducing our new store program, putting more behind our multi-channel strategy.

Of course, it's not easy to drive change in the current environment and you've seen how events in Asia and Europe haven't helped us in the first half. But this has not weakened our resolve and I'm confident that the steps we've taken move us closer to a Tesco which delivers sustainable growth, improving returns and strong cash generation. There's much, much more to do and I'm pleased that we have a strong team now in place, highly experienced, energized and focused. Together, we're making progress towards becoming a global leader in multi-channel retailing.
Thanks for listening and I'll now hand you over to Laurie. Laurie?

Thank you, Philip. Good morning, everyone. I'm going to start my presentation with a summary of the group results, followed by a brief commentary on our segmental performance. I'll then cover the balance sheet and cash flow position, including an update on property, capital and returns. So group sales for the half year were £36 billion, up 1.4% at actual rates, but up 3.2% at constant rates.

Profit reduced on the key income lines, largely reflecting the margin reset in the UK we announced last January and the unhelpful macroeconomic environment. Group trading profit was down 10.5% to £1.6 billion and underlying profit declined by 8.5%. Group profit before tax decreased by 11.6%. Our underlying diluted earnings per share was 17.08p and this has decreased by 7.9% at constant tax rates.

The board has decided to maintain the interim dividend in line with last year at 4.63p per share. By doing this, we are demonstrating our confidence in the group's growth prospects beyond this year and progress that is being made in implementing the UK plan.

Net debt at £7.2 billion is £0.4 billion lower than this time last year. And that's driven mainly by a reduction in capital spending and the benefits from our property divestment program in Thailand and South Korea. Consistent with previous years, this is higher than the year-end debt of £6.8 billion, reflecting the cash outflow from the final dividend payment.

Now turning to the segmental performance. In the UK, despite trading conditions being tough, we're in line with our plans and projections. As a result of our six-part plan, our sales performance improved during the first half. Like-for-like lifted from negative 1.4% in Q1 to 0.2% positive in quarter two. Our actions to improve our competitiveness have started to gain traction with customers. The volume improvement was stronger than the headline like-for-like change between quarter one and two.

And within the mix, grocery like-for-like strengthened and we saw a promising turnaround in fresh foods' performance. And clothing like-for-like also showed a marked improvement. In contrast, hardlines like-for-like remained mid-single digit negative throughout the half, not helped by the continuing structural decline in CDs and DVDs and games, and the early effect of reducing non-space in some existing stores.
Overall, total sales growth excluding petrol was 2.7%, driven by strong new store growth of 3.3%. This increase puts us back in the pack. And in food, our growth actually outperformed the market.

Our trading profit and margin performance reflects our planned investment and is consistent with the guidance we gave in April. Trading margin was 5.2% in the first half, around 90 basis points lower than this time last year, and tracking in line with our expectations. We expect a similar margin for the rest of this year for reasons that I explained at the prelims.

The results of our Asia business have been significantly impacted by change in the regulatory environment in South Korea, our largest market outside the U.K. The legislation has affected not just our own trading, but also that of our tenants as well. Profits were down significantly in Korea during the first half as a direct consequence. And based on our current understanding of the situation, we anticipate the profit impact to be approximately £100 million for the year and weighted towards the second half.

Asia profit was down 1.7% at constant exchange rates in the first half. But looking beyond the regulatory impact in Korea, Asia profits were up mid-single digits, driven by a strong performance in Thailand.

In China, we're adjusting our approach and having more capital discipline. Firstly, by taking a more focused approach on our expansion. Secondly, concentrating on leasehold standalone stores while developing out our committed Lifespace malls. And thirdly, by closing a small number of underperforming stores. And finally, by restructuring some of the regional support costs to lower overheads. The costs linked to this restructuring represent most of the £38 million restructuring charges accounted for in the first half.

In Europe, profits were down by 28%, not helped, of course, by adverse currency movements. And in constant rates, profits reduced by 21%. The key issue here is the further deterioration in the economic environment and consumer confidence. Inevitably, discretionary spending has been hit hardest, and we have taken action across our markets to mark down and clear overstocks. This had particularly impacted general merchandise and has contributed to around £20 million of margin reduction year-on-year.

Our relative performance remained strong, with us gaining or holding market share in the majority of our countries. And we've decided that – and we've achieved that, sorry, on nearly 20% lower capital year-on-year. We've continued to absorb the Hungarian crisis tax charge within our trading profits at a similar level to last year and are hopeful that we'll see a relief from early 2013, when the sunset clause legislation takes effect.

Fresh & Easy delivered a small reduction in losses in the first half at constant rates, with like-for-like sales performance strengthening through the period. As previously announced, we're adopting a more measured approach to capital and are continuing to focus on store-level profitability. We've reviewed the size and shape of our central cost base to ensure it's aligned with that of the business in the near term; and as a result, reduce the number of rolls. This will lower overhead cost by some £5 million this year.

These changes will help the pace of loss reduction during the second half, but more importantly, the trend towards our store-level profitability in established stores remains strong and will continue. As a reminder, I showed you this graph at the preliminary results in April. The 30 stores on the right of the line were already making a positive contribution. Since then, as you can see, an additional 25 have crossed over to positive EBITDA, taking the total now to 55 stores and we expect a further 30 to cross over the line in the second half.

Next year's store opening program is significantly smaller and that's partly about capital discipline, but it should also contribute significantly to the rate of reduction and losses. The immature stores still drag on performance, so not adding new and initially loss-making stores will help a lot. To gauge it for you, our like-for-like stores improved their profitability by $18 million in the first half and that was almost balanced by the drag effect of the new stores we did open.

As Phil mentioned, we're very pleased to say that the bank has now successfully completed its migration and I said at the prelims that we held back our marketing in new and existing products during the final stages to maximize our contingency capability. As a result of this and, also, weaker conditions in the insurance markets, revenue fell by about 1.5%.
Trading profit for the bank did increased by 114% to £94 million. However, this reflects the additional £57 million of PPI that was taken in last year's numbers.

Now, in common with other retail banks, we've also continued to review the level of provisioning for PPI and in the past six months, we, like others in the sector, experienced an increase in claims and therefore, feel it's appropriate to increase our provision by a further £30 million. This leaves our net provision of £78 million at the half year, which is similar to the net provision that we had at the full year. The bank's income statement has benefited from a one-off credit following the settlement of a dispute with a former business partner.

Excluding PPI, fair value and the one-off credit, the bank's baseline profit was flat. And by managing our risk profile, we've seen our bad debt position improve for both credit cards and for loans and our bad debt asset ratio has improved from 2.7% to 1.8% and in light of this, we've released a provision of £10 million.

The bank's overall capital and funding position remains strong, with the risk asset ratio strengthening to 16.9% and the Core Tier 1 ratio increasing by 150 basis points to 16.8% from the year-end. This will be helped further by the termination of the insurance distribution agreement that we had with RBS, resulting in £259 million of capital being repaid to us before the year-end.

Entry in the mortgage market has been a significant milestone for the bank. We've begun lending at a range of loan to values of up to 80%. We have two products in the top five lead tables and the initial customer response is encouraging after only a few weeks. So, to sum up on the bank, although the conditions in the motor insurance market remained unhelpful, with migration now complete and with a strong funding position, we can now begin to fulfill the bank's potential.

Turning now to the group balance sheet. Group capital expenditure in the first half was £1.6 billion and that's a marked reduction compared to the first half of last year. We now expect the full year CapEx to be £3.2 billion, significantly cutting our spending versus last year by 16%, and this is largely driven by the reduced new store opening program in the UK.

Our cash flow from retail activities in the first half was £1.3 billion, and that was down £0.6 billion on last year. A third of this is attributable to the reduction in operating profit. The other components are £0.2 billion from a one-off pension contribution and £0.1 billion from working capital outflow, driven by the timing of rent and other payables.

That timing will normalize and combined with the work that we're doing to reduce stock, we should see a more normal capital inflow of around £0.3 billion by the yearend. Net debt improved year-on-year by £0.4 billion and we expect to see a similar level of improvement in net debt by the yearend and this is in line with our plans to deleverage further.

Despite the small reduction in net debt year-on-year, net finance cost rose by £75 million for two main reasons. Firstly, the non-cash movements in IAS 32 and IAS 39, which moved adversely versus last year, the substantial credit on the revaluation of the minority interest in the Homeplus buyback and also, the impact of marking-to-market some of our hedging contracts were the key drivers.

Secondly, our decision to issue £1.2 billion of new bonds several months ahead of retiring some maturing debt in September of this year, so we had some double running. We successfully completed our first property transactions in Asia in the first half. And in line with our stated objective of releasing more value from our international property portfolio, our property profits were £324 million in the first half.

The listing of our Thai property fund generated £379 million of proceeds by releasing value from 17 malls while still anchored by a Tesco Lotus hypermarket, but we completed that just after the yearend.

The listings continued to trade well, but we're currently in the early stages of injecting a further five malls, which we'll complete in the second half of the year. We're also pleased with the strong demand for the sale and leasebacks of the four Korean hypermarkets in August, and this raised further proceeds of £300 million.

Finally, on the balance sheet, our IAS 19 pension deficit on a post-tax basis has increased to £1.8 billion. This was due to the increase in the discount rate for valuing the funds and future liabilities, as well as lower than assumed asset returns – decrease, sorry, in the discount rate. In anticipation of the outcome of the 2011 triennial actuarial evaluation, we've made a one-off contribution of £180 million to the scheme earlier this year.

I normally update on four key financial metrics, around capital, debt and returns, and our commitment to deliver improvements in these metrics remains. However, the speed with which the improvements are delivered are clearly more challenging in the current environment. For example, it was already clear that hitting our ROCE target in 2014-2015 timeframe was challenging. We acknowledged that in April and of course, it's even more so today.

We remain determined to improve our returns and we've demonstrated our continued commitment to this with the changes that we've made to our capital investment plans. Okay. Thank you. Am I answering you, or... So, let's be clear on the facts. So, South Korea, so far, in the first half of the year, we've been closed five Sundays, all our stores. On a Sunday, we take 20% of our trade. Some customers are adjusting to trade with us on other days. So, we're recouping somewhere between 20% and 30% of the 20% that we lose. So, net 14%, if you like. It not only impacts ourselves, but as you've been around our South Korean stores, you know we've got a lot of tenants in there, as well. So they're effectively closed. We lose the tenant income.

The second factor is the 24-hour trading, and we're one of the very few retailers in Korea that does 24-hour trading. And we've not been able to 24-hour trade for 13 weeks. So combine those two effects, the Sunday trading hit us by about 2.9% negative like-for-like, and the 24-hour trading, about 1.5% negative like-for-like. That's the first half.

And of the £100 million, to size it for you, we said it was more second half weighted. It's about 30% this half, 70% the next half. So, the step-up with more Sundays closed is roughly about 5.7% negative like-for-like and about 1.5% negative like-for-like again from the 24-hour impact. So, of course, flowing that forward through to next year, you get the £70 million impact that we're absorbing it in the second half of this year, lapping a £30 million impact from the first half of this year next year. So, there will be some more impacts for the first half of 2014 and then we should start to lap it.

Yes. I'm going to give both of those to Laurie. So what are we saying about new store remodels and what's happening to sales uplift? And why is it $10 million a throw in the U.S. on average and $1 million for the dollar stores?

We're also putting in further services like coffee machines, like eating areas that are not in the dollar stores. The average uplift for the remodel, the refreshed stores, we're saying it's a contribution of about 1% like-for-like. To come back on those two points, are we to – have you got many freehold stores in the U.S.? Are most of the stores freehold or a portion of them? And then on the uplift, just from what you're saying, are you saying essentially Fresh is up 4% to 5% within the store?

Yes, that's correct, because there's hardly any impact. In fact non-food is probably down, because we're taking out non-food space. If you take the Bishop's Stortford store that you may have been to, it was roughly 70/30 non-food – food to non-food. It's much more 80/20 now to food versus non-food. And then your second question, which is about freeholds, the structure in the U.S. is quite different. Quite often, you end up owning the store, but you don't own the land. On the outlook for the UK consumer, we track a group of families. We've been tracking them for quite a while. We call them Tesco families, because they do video diaries for us. They're resigned to this being the new norm. They see the disposable income squeeze and they're having to become very savvy about how they shop. We have a family, a middle-income family in Britain, man, wife, three daughters.
